questions.text: Which type of immunity is characterized by the production of antibodies by B cells?
What is the primary function of T-helper cells (CD4+ T cells)?
options: Assist in the activation of B cells and other immune cells

questions.text: Which organ is primarily responsible for the maturation of T lymphocytes?
Which of the following is NOT a component of the innate immune system?
Which class of immunoglobulins is the most abundant in the blood and provides long-term immunity?
Which cells are responsible for the phagocytosis of pathogens in the bloodstream and tissues?
In the context of immunology, what does the term "autoimmune disease" refer to?
options: A disease where the immune system attacks the body's own tissues
A disease where there is a complete lack of immune response
A disease caused by a pathogen
A disease resulting from an overactive immune response to external antigens

questions.text: What role do macrophages play in the immune response?
options: They present antigens to T cells

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines is known for its role in fever production during an infection?
Active immunity can be acquired through natural infection or vaccination
Which of the following is an example of active immunity?
Active immunity is provided by antibodies that are introduced into the body from an external source
Active immunity is typically more specific to a pathogen compared to passive immunity
Booster doses of vaccines can help to enhance and prolong the effects of active immunity
The development of active immunity takes immediate effect after exposure to the pathogen
What is the primary benefit of active immunity over passive immunity?
options: Active immunity lasts longer and provides memory for future exposure
Active immunity is not affected by booster doses
Active immunity does not require any prior exposure

questions.text: How long does active immunity typically last?
options: It lasts only as long as the antibody is present in the blood

questions.text: What is active immunity?
options: Immunity developed by exposure to a pathogen or vaccine
Immunity that occurs immediately after exposure to a pathogen
Immunity developed through the transfer of antibodies from another individual

questions.text: Which of the following statements about memory B-cells is true?
options: They are responsible for the rapid response during a secondary immune response
They can only recognise antigens that they have previously encountered.
They produce antibodies immediately upon first exposure to an antigen
They are produced during the primary immune response and remain inactive

questions.text: How do vaccines enhance humoral immunity?
options: By introducing antigens that stimulate B-cells to produce specific antibodies
By providing ready-made antibodies from another individual
By boosting the production of cytokines

questions.text: What role do antibodies play in the immune response?
options: They neutralise toxins and enhance phagocytosis

questions.text: What is the primary function of plasma cells in the humoral immune response?
Which immunoglobulin is the most abundant in the blood and provides long-term protection against pathogens?
What type of immunity is generated by the administration of a vaccine?
Which immunoglobulin is associated with allergic reactions and parasitic infections?
What is humoral immunity primarily mediated by?
During the primary immune response, which immunoglobulin is typically the first to be produced?
The lymphatic system plays a critical role in the immune response by transporting and filtering lymphatic fluid
Which lymphatic structure is located in the upper left quadrant of the abdomen and is involved in filtering blood?
The primary function of lymph nodes is to
Lymph is a clear fluid that resembles blood plasma but lacks red blood cells
Which of the following is NOT a primary component of the lymphatic system?
The tonsils are part of the lymphatic system and help protect against pathogens entering through the mouth and nose
Where does the lymphatic system ultimately drain into the circulatory system?
The thoracic duct is the larger of the two main lymphatic ducts and drains lymph from the upper right side of the body
The lymphatic system is a one-way system that returns lymph to the heart
Which of the following lymphatic structures is primarily responsible for the maturation of T lymphocytes?
What is the primary function of the lymphatic system?
Which of the following structures is NOT part of the lymphatic system?
What fluid is transported by the lymphatic system?
The lymphatic system plays a crucial role in:
Which type of lymphatic vessel is responsible for absorbing dietary fats from the small intestine?
Where do lymphatic vessels primarily drain into the circulatory system?
What is the function of lymph nodes?
Which organ is involved in the maturation of T lymphocytes?
The spleen's primary functions include
options: Filtration of blood and immune response

questions.text: What is the term for the condition where lymphatic vessels become obstructed, leading to fluid accumulation in tissues?
Which lymphatic structure collects lymph from the lower body and left side of the body?
What is the primary role of lymphocytes within the lymphatic system?
What is the role of the lymphatic capillaries in the tissue fluid exchange process?
options: Absorb excess interstitial fluid and return it to the bloodstream
Remove carbon dioxide from the tissues

questions.text: In which lymphatic organ is lymphoid tissue primarily concentrated?
What is the significance of the "cisterna chyli" in the lymphatic system?
options: It is a large lymphatic reservoir that receives lymph from the lower body
It filters blood from the liver
It is an organ involved in red blood cell destruction
It is a major lymph node in the abdomen

questions.text: Which of the following describes an example of a pathogenic microorganism in the human body?
options: Staphylococcus aureus causing a skin infection
Human gut bacteria breaking down fibre
Lactic acid bacteria preventing harmful bacteria growth

questions.text: The human gut microbiota plays an important role in
Which of the following is an example of parasitism?
options: Malaria-causing Plasmodium parasite in the bloodstream of humans
E. coli bacteria in the intestines providing vitamin K to humans
Lichens formed by a fungus and an alga
Skin bacteria that do not harm or benefit humans

questions.text: Which type of microorganism causes tuberculosis?
What is the relationship between the human skin and the microorganisms that normally reside there?
Which of the following is a type of relationship where one organism benefits and the other is neither helped nor harmed?
Which of the following is an example of mutualism in humans?
options: Bacteria in the intestines that help digest food

questions.text: A relationship in which one organism benefits and the other is harmed, but not necessarily killed, is called
Which of the following is NOT a classification of microorganisms?
What type of microorganism is responsible for causing the flu in humans?
What is the relationship between humans and the bacteria in the gut that help break down complex carbohydrates?
Which of the following is an example of an opportunistic pathogen?
options: Candida albicans causing infection in immunocompromised individuals
Clostridium botulinum causing botulism in healthy individuals
Mycobacterium tuberculosis causing lung disease in healthy individuals

questions.text: What is the term for microorganisms that are capable of causing diseases?
What term describes the relationship between two organisms where both organisms benefit?
Which of the following microorganisms is responsible for the infection known as "athlete's foot"?
Which of the following is an example of commensalism?
Which of the following human-associated bacteria is an example of a pathogen that can cause a urinary tract infection?
Which of the following is true regarding the role of fungi in human health?
options: Fungi can be pathogens causing infections like athlete's foot or ringworm
Fungi never cause disease in humans
Fungi are typically beneficial and help digest food

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the role of microorganisms in the human body?
options: They can be harmful, beneficial, or neutral
They have no impact on the human body

questions.text: Which of the following is TRUE about biofilms?
options: Biofilms can be found on medical devices and tissues, and they can increase resistance to antibiotics
They are always harmful to the human body
Biofilms are never found in hospitals

questions.text: What type of infection is commonly associated with the formation of biofilms on indwelling medical devices?
What is the human microbiota?
options: The community of microorganisms (bacteria, viruses, fungi, etc.) that live in and on the human body
A single species of bacteria living in the body
A group of harmful bacteria only found in the intestines

questions.text: What is a biofilm?
options: A community of microorganisms embedded in a protective layer of extracellular polymeric substances (EPS)
A single-celled organism found in the human body
A natural antibiotic produced by bacteria

questions.text: Which of these factors contributes to the formation of biofilms?
options: Surface adhesion and availability of nutrients

questions.text: Which of the following is a benefit of probiotics for human health?
options: They can help restore the balance of the microbiota, especially after antibiotic treatment
They can eliminate all harmful bacteria in the body

questions.text: What are probiotics?
options: Live microorganisms that provide health benefits when consumed in adequate amounts

questions.text: How do antibiotics contribute to the formation of antibiotic-resistant biofilms?
options: They select for bacteria that can survive in the presence of antibiotics, encouraging the development of resistance
They prevent the biofilm from forming
They promote the growth of the biofilm

questions.text: What is an example of a disease that can be caused by an imbalance in the microbiota?
Which of the following is an example of a prebiotic?
options: Garlic and onions, which support the growth of beneficial bacteria

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site for microbial colonization in the human body?
What is one of the most common clinical implications of biofilms in healthcare settings?
options: They increase the difficulty in treating infections, as biofilms are more resistant to antibiotics
They cause rapid recovery from infections
They make it easier to treat infections with antibiotics

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of the microbiota of the skin?
options: It contains a variety of microorganisms that help protect the skin from harmful bacteria
It is composed mostly of harmful pathogens
It is sterile in healthy individuals

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the relationship between the microbiota and human health?
options: A balanced microbiota is essential for optimal health, helping with digestion, immune response, and protection against pathogens
The microbiota is always harmful and should be eradicated
The microbiota has no impact on human health
The microbiota only affects the digestive system

questions.text: What is the role of biotics in managing health?
options: They can be used to maintain a balanced microbiota, supporting immune function, digestion, and other aspects of health
Biotics are only used in the treatment of bacterial infections
They serve as a cure for all diseases
They are synthetic compounds that harm the microbiota.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary buffer system in the human body?
Which of the following conditions is a result of respiratory alkalosis?
Which organ is primarily responsible for regulating the bicarbonate buffer system?
Which of the following would likely cause metabolic alkalosis?
If the pH of the blood falls below 7.35, what condition is it indicative of?
What happens when the pH of the blood becomes too acidic?
Which of the following can cause metabolic acidosis?
What is the role of a buffer in the body?
options: To neutralise excessive hydrogen ions (H+) or hydroxide ions (OH-)
To increase the pH of the urine
To increase the acidity of body fluids

questions.text: How does the body compensate for respiratory acidosis?
options: The body releases more hydrogen ions
